title: Claims that adopting a power pose can boost your confidence are based on 'rubbish research'
text:
There is no evidence to suggest the power stance boosts people's confidence, according to a study.

The wide-legged, chest-out pose – which has been used by Beyoncé, Cristiano Ronaldo and Conservative politicians in the UK – became popular in 2010.

A study had claimed that adopting an expansive physical stance lowered levels of the stress-indicating hormone cortisol, raised testosterone and made you feel powerful.

However, the findings were met with scepticism after other researchers were unable to replicate the results of the study.

The controversy resurfaced when the authors published an updated analysis of both their original work and other people's posing studies to support their claims.

Now, a US researcher has analysed the body of existing research on power posing and found that most are poorly designed or found no meaningful effect.

Scroll down for video

Power posing does not work, with there being no evidence to suggest that the large stances give the confidence boost they are often credited with, a study finds. Pictured, Theresa May

Psychologist Marcus Credé of the Iowa State University reviewed every single published study into power poses, exploring their methods and analyses.

He found that nearly all of the studies had been poorly designed and only compared power poses to contractive stances, like slouching, rather than normal poses.

According to Professor Credé, this oversight has distorted the results, as it is impossible to tell if the power pose is making you feel better or if the contractive pose just makes you feel worse.

'There has literally never been a study that compared a power pose to a normal pose and found any positive effect for a power pose,' Professor Credé said.

'I find this pretty stunning because of the multi-million-dollar industry that has been built up around power posing.'

'It is not dissimilar to a drug being sold to the public without a single study ever having been able to show that the drug works better than placebo or doing nothing.'

The power pose — assuming the kind of large stance popularised by Wonder Woman, or Beyoncé, pictured left — became popular in 2010. Right, MP Sajid Javid

A 2010 study had claimed that adopting an expansive physical stance lowered levels of the stress-indicating hormone cortisol, raised testosterone made you feel powerful. Pictured, Lynda Carter as Woman Woman, assuming her iconic pose

In fact, Professor Credé said that only four of the nearly 40 studies into power posing were designed in a way that could properly explore the stance's impact.

One of these studies, for example, examined how dominant people felt when assuming slouched, neutral and power poses.

Yet it found that people's feelings of dominance were highest when assuming a neutral stance — and that the power pose was instead associated with feeling less powerful in comparison.

The other three studies, which examined the effect of the three poses on mood, did find that the different poses elicited feelings.

However, Professor Credé noted that the results of all these studies were driven by the negative effect of the slouching stance, rather than any positive effect coming from power posing.

A US researcher has analysed the body of existing research on power posing and found that most are poorly designed or found no meaningful effect

'The only conclusion researchers should draw from the existing literature on postural feedback is that contractive poses such as slouching should be avoided, which is hardly novel,' Professor Credé said.

'I recall my elementary school teachers yelling at us about slouching and not what has been sold here.'

The full findings of the study were published in the journal Meta-Psychology.
